importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the AWS outage reported in the article, highlighting a recent global internet disruption.
The last major AWS outage occurred in 2021, showing a pattern of recurrence and prompting concerns about system resilience.
Reference to the largest-ever IT outage in 2024, when a CrowdStrike software glitch caused global disruptions, emphasizing the vulnerability of cloud-dependent systems.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The outage began in the evening and was resolved by 6:35 AM ET, indicating the duration and time-sensitive nature of the disruption.

keyTakeAways: The internet's backbone is fragile due to its heavy reliance on a small number of cloud providers, such as Amazon Web Services (AWS).
A DNS malfunction caused AWS services to become inaccessible, preventing websites and apps from accessing data stored in DynamoDB.
The outage affected a wide range of services, including banking, social media, airline booking, and e-commerce platforms.
This event underscores the lack of redundancy and competition in cloud infrastructure, with many companies relying on a single provider.
Experts note that the internet was designed to be decentralized and resilient, but current reliance on centralized cloud regions makes it vulnerable to localized failures.
The root cause remains unclear, but it is not believed to be a cyberattack, and is likely a technical fault in AWS's DNS or data center systems.

namedEntities.name: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cloud computing platform that hosts critical online services such as banking, social media, e-commerce, and airline booking systems.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: AWS went down for several hours, causing widespread disruption across the internet, demonstrating the fragility of the modern digital ecosystem.

namedEntities.name: Domain Name System (DNS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A system that converts user-friendly web addresses (like amazon.com) into IP addresses that computers can understand.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The DNS malfunction prevented access to AWS-hosted databases, causing apps and websites to become temporarily inaccessible.

namedEntities.name: DynamoDB
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A database service hosted by AWS that stores customer data for various companies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Customer data could not be accessed due to the DNS failure, leading to temporary disconnection of apps from their data sources.

namedEntities.name: CrowdStrike
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cybersecurity software company whose flawed update caused a global IT outage in 2024.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Historically, similar large-scale outages have occurred due to software bugs, illustrating the recurring risk in cloud-dependent systems.

namedEntities.name: AT&T
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major telecommunications provider that experienced network outages, including an 11-hour meltdown last year.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Demonstrates that infrastructure failures in telecom services also disrupt digital operations and gig economy jobs.

namedEntities.name: Rob Jardin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief digital officer at NymVPN, a cybersecurity firm.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provided expert commentary on the fragility of centralized cloud systems and the impact of single-point failures.

namedEntities.name: Mike Chapple
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Cybersecurity expert and IT professor at the University of Notre Dame.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Offered analysis on why such outages gain public attention due to their widespread impact on critical services.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amazon Web Services (AWS) experienced a major global outage on Monday, October 20, 2025, lasting several hours and affecting numerous online services such as banking, social media, e-commerce, and airline booking. The root cause was a failure in the Domain Name System (DNS), which prevented websites and apps from accessing data stored in AWS’s DynamoDB service. Despite no evidence of a cyberattack, the incident highlights the fragility of the internet’s infrastructure due to overreliance on a few centralized cloud providers. Experts warn that without better redundancies and competitive cloud options, such outages will continue to have widespread consequences, reinforcing the need for more resilient and decentralized digital systems.
title: The internet just had another global outage. Why does this keep happening?
